author.ban_reason: Repeated deliberate violations of Guildmaster rules

body:
The more I read, the more I notice the connections. That's when it came to me... what if they aren't copies of the same stories, but the same story from different angles? Like the Great Flood, I implore that you look into Ragnarok and try to honestly tell me they aren't the same events shot at a different angle. Or perhaps the confirmation of the Egyptian Gods definitely being real by Bible canon; God cannot judge that which doesn't exist. Under this idea, I've been able to fill multiple gaps during my reading. The stone David threw? I bet it was an Omphalos stone. Why? Though God can make miracles happen outright, He prefers having method. When it describes the Four Horsemen bringing Hades as though it is an alternate name for Hell, what if it actually means that Underworld God Hades merely accompanied them, likely as a Leader. And by extension, hence the painless and sudden disappearance of those in Rapture, what if the Horseman of Death is specifically Thanatos? The evidence isn't always there, but when it is it works and I haven't necessarily stumbled upon anything to disprove this. 

Do you agree with this? Tell me what you think.

Like the Great Flood, I implore that you look into Ragnarok and try to honestly tell me they aren't the same events shot at a different angle. Or perhaps the confirmation of the Egyptian Gods definitely being real by Bible canon; God cannot judge that which doesn't exist. Under this idea, I've been able to fill multiple gaps during my reading. The stone David threw? I bet it was an Omphalos stone. Why? Though God can make miracles happen outright, He prefers having method. When it describes the Four Horsemen bringing Hades as though it is an alternate name for Hell, what if it actually means that Underworld God Hades merely accompanied them, likely as a Leader. And by extension, hence the painless and sudden disappearance of those in Rapture, what if the Horseman of Death is specifically Thanatos? The evidence isn't always there, but when it is it works and I haven't necessarily stumbled upon anything to disprove this.

Do you agree with this? Tell me what you think.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

post.body:
The more I read, the more I notice the connections. That's when it came to me... what if they aren't copies of the same stories, but the same story from different angles? Like the Great Flood, I implore that you look into Ragnarok and try to honestly tell me they aren't the same events shot at a different angle. Or perhaps the confirmation of the Egyptian Gods definitely being real by Bible canon; God cannot judge that which doesn't exist. Under this idea, I've been able to fill multiple gaps during my reading. The stone David threw? I bet it was an Omphalos stone. Why? Though God can make miracles happen outright, He prefers having method. When it describes the Four Horsemen bringing Hades as though it is an alternate name for Hell, what if it actually means that Underworld God Hades merely accompanied them, likely as a Leader. And by extension, hence the painless and sudden disappearance of those in Rapture, what if the Horseman of Death is specifically Thanatos? The evidence isn't always there, but when it is it works and I haven't necessarily stumbled upon anything to disprove this. 

Do you agree with this? Tell me what you think.

body: I recommend you read "The Unseen Realm" by Michael S. Heiser — there's a lot about spiritual beings other than Yahweh (the one and only God) spoken of in the bible that has gotten lost, overlooked, misunderstood, or shoved under the rug in modern Christianity. The fact that the Hebrew word for a spiritual being, "elohim", can refer to either the singular, upper-case-g "God", or contextually, as a plural (translated as lower-case-g "gods") lends to the confusion. For example: Psalm 82:1 "God (_elohim_) stands in the assembly of El; in the midst of the gods (_elohim_) he renders judgment." These spiritual beings (what we might call angels — although "angel" [messenger], is a job title) — are not "gods" like we would think of the term today, but they were supposed to be shepherding the nations but instead disobeyed and received worship themselves and led humanity astray.
body_html: I recommend you read "The Unseen Realm" by Michael S. Heiser — there's a lot about spiritual beings other than Yahweh (the one and only God) spoken of in the bible that has gotten lost, overlooked, misunderstood, or shoved under the rug in modern Christianity. The fact that the Hebrew word for a spiritual being, "elohim", can refer to either the singular, upper-case-g "God", or contextually, as a plural (translated as lower-case-g "gods") lends to the confusion. For example: Psalm 82:1 "God (elohim) stands in the assembly of El; in the midst of the gods (elohim) he renders judgment." These spiritual beings (what we might call angels — although "angel" [messenger], is a job title) — are not "gods" like we would think of the term today, but they were supposed to be shepherding the nations but instead disobeyed and received worship themselves and led humanity astray.

body:
Ehhhhhhhh

There is one truth of this world. However everyone is trying to understand. However God revealed Himself in one way and there is one path to Him. Do many cultures have global flood myths? Yes. Did a global flood happen? Yes. But the tale of Noah is the story. The rest people made up other ideas.

16 While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, he was greatly distressed to see that the city was full of idols. 17 So he reasoned in the synagogue with both Jews and God-fearing Greeks, as well as in the marketplace day by day with those who happened to be there. 18 A group of Epicurean and Stoic philosophers began to debate with him. Some of them asked, “What is this babbler trying to say?” Others remarked, “He seems to be advocating foreign gods.” They said this because Paul was preaching the good news about Jesus and the resurrection. 19 Then they took him and brought him to a meeting of the Areopagus, where they said to him, “May we know what this new teaching is that you are presenting? 20 You are bringing some strange ideas to our ears, and we would like to know what they mean.” 21 (All the Athenians and the foreigners who lived there spent their time doing nothing but talking about and listening to the latest ideas.)

22 Paul then stood up in the meeting of the Areopagus and said: “People of Athens! I see that in every way you are very religious. 23 For as I walked around and looked carefully at your objects of worship, I even found an altar with this inscription: to an unknown god. So you are ignorant of the very thing you worship—and this is what I am going to proclaim to you.

24 “The God who made the world and everything in it is the Lord of heaven and earth and does not live in temples built by human hands. 25 And he is not served by human hands, as if he needed anything. Rather, he himself gives everyone life and breath and everything else. 26 From one man he made all the nations, that they should inhabit the whole earth; and he marked out their appointed times in history and the boundaries of their lands. 27 God did this so that they would seek him and perhaps reach out for him and find him, though he is not far from any one of us. 28 ‘For in him we live and move and have our being.’[b] As some of your own poets have said, ‘We are his offspring.’[c]

29 “Therefore since we are God’s offspring, we should not think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone—an image made by human design and skill. 30 In the past God overlooked such ignorance, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent. 31 For he has set a day when he will judge the world with justice by the man he has appointed. He has given proof of this to everyone by raising him from the dead.”

Acts 17:16-31

The story of the fall of Babel is one of most interesting in human history. A city of human and spiritual rebellion against God. God told humanity to spread over the earth, but they gathered in the one city of Babylon and worshipped false “gods” fallen angels (demons) in the form entities like Moloch the god of child sacrifice. God decided to humble their arrogance and further his command by doing something only God can  do—He confused their languages to divide them into nations and have them over to the fallen spiritual rebels they wanted to worship. God decided instead to be faithful to one people group and show how much better it was to follow Him in comparison. That is why for much of history God left other cultures to themselves. But in Jesus called once again all nations to follow Him. 

https://youtu.be/CamYtVpoTNk

I suggest you do some cultural research into ancient Middle East history and culture. 

Btw there’s tons of artifacts and historical documents for events in the Bible. That archeology will never be popularized by the media, but it’s available.

29 “Therefore since we are God’s offspring, we should not think that the divine being is like gold or silver or stone—an image made by human design and skill. 30 In the past God overlooked such ignorance, but now he commands all people everywhere to repent. 31 For he has set a day when he will judge the world with justice by the man he has appointed. But in Jesus called once again all nations to follow Him.

I suggest you do some cultural research into ancient Middle East history and culture.

Btw there’s tons of artifacts and historical documents for events in the Bible. That archeology will never be popularized by the media, but it’s available.

For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. post.body:
The more I read, the more I notice the connections. That's when it came to me... what if they aren't copies of the same stories, but the same story from different angles? Like the Great Flood, I implore that you look into Ragnarok and try to honestly tell me they aren't the same events shot at a different angle. Or perhaps the confirmation of the Egyptian Gods definitely being real by Bible canon; God cannot judge that which doesn't exist. Under this idea, I've been able to fill multiple gaps during my reading. The stone David threw? I bet it was an Omphalos stone. Why? Though God can make miracles happen outright, He prefers having method. When it describes the Four Horsemen bringing Hades as though it is an alternate name for Hell, what if it actually means that Underworld God Hades merely accompanied them, likely as a Leader. And by extension, hence the painless and sudden disappearance of those in Rapture, what if the Horseman of Death is specifically Thanatos? The evidence isn't always there, but when it is it works and I haven't necessarily stumbled upon anything to disprove this. 

Do you agree with this? Tell me what you think.

Though God can make miracles happen outright, He prefers having method. When it describes the Four Horsemen bringing Hades as though it is an alternate name for Hell, what if it actually means that Underworld God Hades merely accompanied them, likely as a Leader. And by extension, hence the painless and sudden disappearance of those in Rapture, what if the Horseman of Death is specifically Thanatos? The evidence isn't always there, but when it is it works and I haven't necessarily stumbled upon anything to disprove this.

Do you agree with this? Tell me what you think.

body: I do tend to think the pagan gods might be real demons. However I wouldn't jump to conclusions. There is plenty of paganism in the old testament, and it's because it was edited by evil scribes to support such atrocity. Things like animal sacrifice, burning people at the stake, racism against Moabites and gentiles, hatred of eunuchs, invading foreign areas for no reason and killing and torturing everyone even the children and animals, priestly hierarchy, prophets killing children for the pettiest reasons, likely circumcision, and all those crazy gut-wrenching passages are later additions by scribes. Probably the really silly and petty rules too like not eating pork. It's hard to date when it first began and I suspect a few changes here and there have been introduced from the beginning as usual. But it appears that when it really picked up was in the time of Josiah. It says he rediscovered the holy and sacred book of rules of God that had somehow been misplaced for years in the temple. Riiiiiiiiiiiiight. And these supposedly "rediscovered" lost books of God very conveniently situated Josiah in positions of power and shat on exactly people he didn't like. He was later killed in battle that God told him not to engage in. Meanwhile Jeremiah was receiving prophesy about this and recorded it in his book which he sent to Josiah's son Jehoiakim, who hated it so much that as soon as he was done reading a page he'd throw it in his fireplace to be burned. This wouldn't be the last major fraud and redaction either, as after the return from the exile in Babylon further redactions were made, garbling the order of the prophets, editing the text to conform with later beliefs, adding even more laws, etc. It is likely that Ezra-Nehemiah are behind this one, whom even orthodox jews admit probably changed the text (interestingly an apocryphal book of Ezra records a story similar to Josiah's, where the law has been supposedly burnt by invading troops so Ezra rewrites it himself, as if there's only one copy of such sacred scripture. Quite an elaborate excuse he spun up if this account is accurate). This is the real reason the new testament contradicts the old testament so much (as well as the old testament itself often times). Because much of it is falsified by scribes. It's also why so many good characters in the old testament had no knowledge about most of the commandments in the old testament we possess today, including ones with penalties of being stoned or burnt at the stake. And finally, it explains why many parts of the bible are out of order, don't line up with each other, contradict each other even in the same passage, and are so complicated and hard to understand. As it stands, you can make it say pretty much anything you want.

There is plenty of paganism in the old testament, and it's because it was edited by evil scribes to support such atrocity. Things like animal sacrifice, burning people at the stake, racism against Moabites and gentiles, hatred of eunuchs, invading foreign areas for no reason and killing and torturing everyone even the children and animals, priestly hierarchy, prophets killing children for the pettiest reasons, likely circumcision, and all those crazy gut-wrenching passages are later additions by scribes. Probably the really silly and petty rules too like not eating pork. It's hard to date when it first began and I suspect a few changes here and there have been introduced from the beginning as usual. But it appears that when it really picked up was in the time of Josiah. It says he rediscovered the holy and sacred book of rules of God that had somehow been misplaced for years in the temple. Riiiiiiiiiiiiight. And these supposedly "rediscovered" lost books of God very conveniently situated Josiah in positions of power and shat on exactly people he didn't like. He was later killed in battle that God told him not to engage in. Meanwhile Jeremiah was receiving prophesy about this and recorded it in his book which he sent to Josiah's son Jehoiakim, who hated it so much that as soon as he was done reading a page he'd throw it in his fireplace to be burned. This wouldn't be the last major fraud and redaction either, as after the return from the exile in Babylon further redactions were made, garbling the order of the prophets, editing the text to conform with later beliefs, adding even more laws, etc. It is likely that Ezra-Nehemiah are behind this one, whom even orthodox jews admit probably changed the text (interestingly an apocryphal book of Ezra records a story similar to Josiah's, where the law has been supposedly burnt by invading troops so Ezra rewrites it himself, as if there's only one copy of such sacred scripture. Quite an elaborate excuse he spun up if this account is accurate). This is the real reason the new testament contradicts the old testament so much (as well as the old testament itself often times). Because much of it is falsified by scribes. It's also why so many good characters in the old testament had no knowledge about most of the commandments in the old testament we possess today, including ones with penalties of being stoned or burnt at the stake. And finally, it explains why many parts of the bible are out of order, don't line up with each other, contradict each other even in the same passage, and are so complicated and hard to understand. As it stands, you can make it say pretty much anything you want.

post.body:
The more I read, the more I notice the connections. That's when it came to me... what if they aren't copies of the same stories, but the same story from different angles? Like the Great Flood, I implore that you look into Ragnarok and try to honestly tell me they aren't the same events shot at a different angle. Or perhaps the confirmation of the Egyptian Gods definitely being real by Bible canon; God cannot judge that which doesn't exist. Under this idea, I've been able to fill multiple gaps during my reading. The stone David threw? I bet it was an Omphalos stone. Why? Though God can make miracles happen outright, He prefers having method. When it describes the Four Horsemen bringing Hades as though it is an alternate name for Hell, what if it actually means that Underworld God Hades merely accompanied them, likely as a Leader. And by extension, hence the painless and sudden disappearance of those in Rapture, what if the Horseman of Death is specifically Thanatos? The evidence isn't always there, but when it is it works and I haven't necessarily stumbled upon anything to disprove this. 

Do you agree with this? Tell me what you think.
